results.title: Research in the atmosphere
results.creator_credit: National Aeronautics and Space Administration and Film Graphics
results.brief_description: Traces the methods of exploring the upper atmosphere and near-earth environment from ancient times until the present, with emphasis on research with balloons and sounding rockets.

results.title: Research for better living
results.creator_credit: Central Office of Information UK and Realist Films
results.brief_description: Shows how Britain’s scientists and technicians at home are helping young and developing countries in their constant fight against disease, pests and poverty, and in their efforts towards a better life.

results.title: Research by rockets
results.creator_credit: Stanley Ruttenberg, Arnold Frutkin, Lothar Wolff and National Academy of Sciences (U.S.)
results.brief_description: The use of rockets as tools for scientific research in the upper atmosphere. How rockets are the means of placing scientific instruments into the high atmosphere in order to measure space phenomena. Includes footage of experimental rocket flights in the 1920’s.

results.title: Research and modern housing
results.creator_credit: Richard F. Tambling, Julian Wintle and Verity Films
results.brief_description: Describes the work and experiments carried out at the Building Research Station of the Department of Scientific and Industrial Research, England. Shows new ideas for better, cheaper and quicker building techniques and the way this is helping to solve postwar housing problems in Britain.

results.title: Rescue by helicopter
results.creator_credit: Bern Gandy, John Martin-Jones, Australia. Royal Australian Navy and Australian Commonwealth Film Unit
results.brief_description: Standard procedures for rescue by a helicopter. Vertical take off and landing, and the ability to hover make it a valuable rescue craft. Shows correct method of approach, putting on the rescue strap, and giving the winding signal. Provided rules are adhered to helicopter rescue is quite safe. Edited by Richard Mitchell.

results.title: Rescue 036
results.creator_credit: Greg Parry and Australia. Dept. of Defence. Public Relations
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Sentinel”.
The Army Aviation Centre at Oakey, Queensland, has more helicopter movements per year than any other airfield in Australia. Therefore the potential of aircraft accidents is great. The Army Aviation Corps have devised a crash rescue system designed to provide medical assistance to crash victims in the shortest possible time.

results.title: Requiem for a faith
results.creator_credit: Elda Hartley, Irving Hartley and Hartley Productions
results.brief_description: The traditional life of Tibet is depicted by Huston Smith, Professor of Philosophy at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology. Smith shows the extent to which traditional customs have been invaded and corroded by the West. All social and economic activity revolves around religious practice. The importance of the Dalai Lama is emphasised. Set in Gyuto Tantric Monastery in Northern India, this moving film explores the essence of Tibetan Buddhism and focuses on the unusual chants of the Gyuto monks, whose training enables them to chant in chords. The film was shot mainly in Dalhousie, India, where the two Tantric Colleges, Gyuto and Gyume, were re-established in exile.

results.title: Requiem for a dream [DVD] (D)
results.creator_credit: Darren Aronofsky, Eric Watson, Thousand Words Productions and Artisan Entertainment
results.brief_description: Although the plot of “Requiem for a dream” revolves around four very human humans, the hero of the film is undoubtedly addiction. Addiction to food, to heroin, to diet pills, and that most everyday habit, to television. If film noir attacked The American Dream, then Darren Aronofsky’s follow-up to “Pi” sees that dream kidnapped, tortured and burned. This is exacted in the junkie lifestyle of Harry and his friends, as well as the loneliness of his mother, portrayed by Ellen Burstyn, whose performance makes “Requiem for a dream” one of the best movies of 2001. A victim to heroin chic but also, eventually, a critic, this film is aimed at a young audience but takes the unusual step of actually having something to say. The screenplay was written by Aronofsky and Hubert Selby Jnr (‘Last Exit To Brooklyn’), based on the latter’s novel. It also features one of the most progressive film soundtracks of recent years, written and performed by Clint Mansell and the Kronos Quartet.

results.title: Requiem by Andrew Lloyd Webber
results.creator_credit: Humphrey Burton, Ian Squires, The Really Useful Group and BBC-TV
results.brief_description: Filmed on location at the St Thomas Church, New York, on Sunday February 24th 1985, the world premiere of Andrew Lloyd Webber’s “Requiem” was performed to an enthusiastic and receptive audience. The wonderful voices of Placido Domingo (tenor), Sarah Brightman (soprano) and Paul Miles-Kingston (treble) supported by the Winchester Cathedral Choir (directed by Martin Neary), The St Thomas Choir (directed by Gerre Hancock) and the Orchestra of St Luke’s conducted by Lorin Maazel give depth and quality to Webber’s original composition.

results.title: Repulsion motor principles
results.creator_credit: United States. Office of Education and Ray-Bell Films
results.brief_description:
Episode number 5 of Series “Electrical work: electrical machinery”.
Explains construction of repulsion motor, rotor circuits and effects of brush position; short-circuiting and brush-lifting mechanism; and application of repulsion motors. This film is a technical training film on the design and construction of repulsion brush type electric A.C. motors as used in the first half of this century.
